prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
By scaling the line flux density of I16342 at the distance to I18286, we estimate a peak of about 640 mJy/beam in the 12CO line. A sensitivity of 60 mJy/beam will then allow us to characterize the spectral profile of the line, reaching a S/N of about 10.
Since our goal is not resolving the molecular envelope but detecting it and collecting all of its emission, we request a synthesized beam of 1'', to limit ISM confusion, and a LAS of 7'', based on the typical sizes of AGB circumstellar envelopes.
A line width of 30 km/s was set. This is what expected (at most) from the remnant AGB envelope.

By scaling the line flux density of I16342 at the distance to I18450, we estimate a peak of about 910 mJy/beam in the 12CO line. A sensitivity of 90 mJy/beam will then allow us to characterize the spectral profile of the line, reaching a S/N of about 10.
Since our goal is not resolving the molecular envelope but detecting it and collecting all of its emission, we request a synthesized beam of 1'', to limit ISM confusion, and a LAS of 7'', based on the typical sizes of AGB circumstellar envelopes.
A line width of 30 km/s was set. This is what expected (at most) from the remnant AGB envelope.

By scaling the line flux density of I16342 at the distance to I18460, we estimate a peak of about 130 mJy/beam in the 12CO line. A sensitivity of 10 mJy/beam will then allow us to characterize the spectral profile of the line, reaching a S/N of about 10.
Since our goal is not resolving the molecular envelope but detecting it and collecting all of its emission, we request a synthesized beam of 1'', to limit ISM confusion, and a LAS of 7'', based on the typical sizes of AGB circumstellar envelopes.
A line width of 30 km/s was set. This is what expected (at most) from the remnant AGB envelope.

By scaling the line flux density of I16342 at the distance to I19134, we estimate a peak of about 100 mJy/beam in the 12CO line. A sensitivity of 10 mJy/beam will then allow us to characterize the spectral profile of the line, reaching a S/N of about 10.
Since our goal is not resolving the molecular envelope but detecting it and collecting all of its emission, we request a synthesized beam of 1'', to limit ISM confusion, and a LAS of 7'', based on the typical sizes of AGB circumstellar envelopes.
A line width of 30 km/s was set. This is what expected (at most) from the remnant AGB envelope.

By scaling the line flux density of I16342 at the distance to I19190, we estimate a peak of about 75 mJy/beam in the 12CO line. A sensitivity of 7 mJy/beam will then allow us to characterize the spectral profile of the line, reaching a S/N of about 10.
Since our goal is not resolving the molecular envelope but detecting it and collecting all of its emission, we request a synthesized beam of 1'', to limit ISM confusion, and a LAS of 7'', based on the typical sizes of AGB circumstellar envelopes.
A line width of 30 km/s was set. This is what expected (at most) from the remnant AGB envelope.

The distance to I18596 is uncertain and indicated to be within 4.5-9 kpc. The source is included in our project, because the J=1-0 and J=2-1 CO lines were recently detected. The peak flux density in the J=2-1 line is about 1.5 Jy/beam. By scaling the J=3-2 flux density of I16342 at a mean distance of 6.5 kpc, we estimate a peak of about 200 mJy/beam. Therefore our request is for a sensitivity of about 20 mJy/beam.
Since our goal is not resolving the molecular envelope but detecting it and collecting all of its emission, we request a synthesized beam of 1'', to limit ISM confusion, and a LAS of 7'', based on the typical sizes of AGB circumstellar envelopes.
A line width of 30 km/s was set. This is what expected (at most) from the remnant AGB envelope.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The evolution from the AGB to the post-AGB stage can be traced in O-rich stars through maser lines of SiO, H2O, and OH molecules. In a small group of evolved stars dubbed as "water fountains", the properties of the maser lines indicate that these may actually be sources that have left the AGB just a few centuries ago and where a jet is currently shaping the circumstellar envelope, creating the complicated structures often observed in post-AGB stars and Planetary Nebulae. Most of what we know about water fountains comes from maser observations, but masers can give very biased views of the properties of the circumstellar envelopes. Much higher reliability can be achieved through CO lines, though these have been detected so far only in three water fountains, in spite of several attempts in others. We propose to use ALMA to detect the J=3-2 rotational transition from 12CO and 13CO in Band 7, as well as adjacent continuum emission, in the water fountains with currently known distances. These observations will allow us to set the evolutionary stage of these rare stars through reliable estimations of their mass-loss rates, gas masses, dust masses, and gas-to-dust mass ratios.
